title: Tooth Injury
summary: Managing knocked-out, broken, or loose teeth. Quick action within 30 minutes can often save a permanent tooth.

steps.title: Control Bleeding
steps.description: Have person rinse mouth gently with warm water. Apply direct pressure to bleeding gums with clean gauze or cloth for 10-15 minutes. Have person bite down on gauze. If severe facial injury, seek immediate care.

steps.title: For Knocked-Out Permanent Tooth
steps.description: Find tooth immediately. Pick up by crown (top), not root. If dirty, rinse briefly with milk or saline - NOT water. Do not scrub or remove tissue. Time is critical - act within 30 minutes.

steps.title: Preserve the Tooth
steps.description: Best: Gently reinsert tooth into socket if possible. Have person bite on gauze to hold in place. Otherwise: Store in milk, saliva (in mouth), or tooth preservation kit. Do NOT store in water or let dry out.

steps.title: For Broken or Chipped Tooth
steps.description: Rinse mouth with warm water. Save any pieces in milk. Apply cold compress to face to reduce swelling. Cover sharp edges with dental wax or sugar-free gum. Avoid hot/cold foods.

steps.title: Seek Dental Care
steps.description: See dentist immediately for knocked-out teeth (within 30 minutes best). Same-day care for broken teeth with exposed nerves (severe pain). Loose baby teeth usually don't need reimplantation but should be evaluated.

warnings: Never touch the root of a knocked-out tooth
Do not reimplant baby teeth - this can damage permanent teeth below
Water damages tooth cells - use milk or saliva for storage
whenToSeekHelp: See dentist within 30 minutes for knocked-out permanent teeth
Seek immediate care for severe pain or nerve exposure
Get same-day evaluation for any tooth injury
